entry.Title: Dan's story

entry.Description:
CT confirmed 12.5 X 9 mass on medial left and right lobes of liver with interior Vena Cava thrombus and compression of right middle hepatic vein. Liver biopsy confirmed FHC. Tumor was pushing up on diaphram causing shoulder pain (due to nerves to shoulder crossing diaphram). Surgeon said too big to operate and would probably need work both sides of the diaphram which was too dangerous

needed blood thinners
chemoembolization with Adriamycin and lipiodol
liver surgery followed by short treatment of sorafenib: stopped due to adverse reactions
left thoracotemy followed by chemo:Capecitabine, bevacizumab and erlotinib
surgery to remove bowel obstruction
chemo resumed: Capecitabine and bevacizumab

recurrence in liver: Micro-Surgery to remove lymph nodes around the frenic vein
Chest radiation with alternating oxaliplatin and cisplatin
5cm tumor removed from pelvic region. Analysis suggested would be susceptible to Irinotecan (primarily) and adriamycin (secondarily).

 Another liver tumor - treated with CyberKnife therapy
chemo: gemcitabine, bevacizumab and irinotecan for@ 5 months stopping first Irinotecan and a month later the other two

3 months later: chemoembolization with adriamycin, cisplatin and mitomycin. Treatment failed.
@ 1month later:Adriamycin and Bevacizumab chemo started - stopped for break after @ 2 months

blood thinners started due to blood clots

surgery for recurrence
Tags: Surgery to Remove Tumors Outside of the Liver

looking for info
entry.Title: Emma

entry.Description: advice on dealing with cancer
entry.Title: Family, Love, & Illness

entry.Description:
4 tumors in liver (3 of around 10 cm and one of 28 cm
metastasis of the lymph nodes, adrenal gland (in only one) and a spot on left lung, probably also a metastasis.


Pre chemo medication: Ranitine (300mg) and Medrol (at first 32mg now 24mg) Medrol eliminated night sweats and tumour fever

Chemo:6 rounds scheduled of cisplatin and doxyrubicin
 after round 3: scan showed that tumors were stable and were no longer growing 
 metastasis of the lymph nodes were even smaller 
 other metastasis also stable.
 end of the 6 rounds, same as after 3 rounds. 

follow up scan: stable condition

Currently: Nexavar: 4x200mg a day

entry.Title: Diagnosed in 1994

entry.Description:
initial surgery aborted: removal of gall bladder to give room for tumours

awaiting liver transplanrtation (eight months): chemoembolization

3 years post transplant: recurrence + metastasis

metastasis not new: undetected at time of transplant (luckily)

contacted Dr. Daniel Mackey (oncologist)

Chemo: Gemzar + Cisplatin for 3 years--- clear scans

1 1/2 years break

tumour returned

Chemo: Nexavar -- tumours grew
 
 switch to:Gemox -- 2 years use:mostly stable disease with a little shrinkage
entry.Title: Kim's Journey with Fibrolamellar

entry.Description:
multiple tumours throughout the body
3 biopsies: diagnosis of FHC
began treatment with Nexavar
Added 5FU/Interferon
After 2 months: tumour in stomach disappeared, others shrank a bit
After 11 months: stable disease
Started taking Essiac Tea and Milk Thistle
After 2 months: scan showed significant response: tumours shrank, some @ 3cm.
entry.Title: My Story

entry.Description:
surgery to remove tumour
recurrence + metastasis: chemo: Nexavar
unable to tolerate
2nd opinion: surgery + radiation followed by chemo: 5FU/Interferon for enlarged lymph nodes
after 3 rounds: some response
6 more rounds:stable disease
cellular therapy
lymph nodes began to grow
surgery to remove them
3 rounds of chemo 5FU/Interferon
no evidence of disease

entry.Title: My FLHCC Story - Tal F

entry.Description:
large mass on liver: not a surgical candidate
Chemo: 5FU/Interferon :no response
 2 rounds of PIAF: no response
 5 rounds of Tarceva: no real response
 1 round of PIAF
became very ill,septic,moved to pediatric ICU
resumed Chemo: Nexavar
1st chemo embolization: successful
6-7 more chemo embolizations: each time drs. were pleased with results
now possibly a liver transplant candidate, waiting for drs. to review info
meantime: some jaundice
taking Nexavar

entry.Title: My husband

entry.Description:
liver resection:remove 10cm tumor + 50 percent of liver + gallbladder
 no signs of metastasis
3 months post op scan: no sign of disease:drain placed at the surgery site due to some infected fluid that had collected
7 month scan showed lesion on upper left lung
wedge resection to remove tumour,which tested positive for FHC
4 months later: tumour on lower right lung: resection
3 months later: a 3rd tumor growing: 3rd wedge resection performed now at Dana Farber
All lung surgeries performed with a scope 
since last wedge resection, @ 1 1/2 years, no evidence of disease
liver remains tumour free
scans to be every 6 months 
still feeling tired

entry.Title: My FHC Story- Amanda R.

entry.Description:
liver resection, metastasis to lymph nodes
Chemo: Xeloda, Nexavar, IFU:1 month post surgery for 6 months intended as adjuvent therapy
7 months later: scan showed suspicious spots
MRI confirmed 8 new tumours; 5 on right side of liver, 3 near aorta
port inserted for Chemo IV: Gemzar, Oxaliplatin and Avastin administered every other week for 7 hours
will scan every 2 cycles
entry.Title: My husbands story - Dustin

entry.Description:
partial liver resection to be followed with scans every 3 months for 1st year, then every 6 months
February 2006:18 months post surgery:para-esophageal mass was found: treated with Chemo:5FU/interferon for 7 months
May 2007:15 months later:radiation to the para-esophageal mass
June 2007:1 month later: Chemo started: Camptosar and Vincristine for 6 months
September 2008: 15 months later:Declined use of Nexavar
March 2009: moved mack to Birmingham, Alabama: new oncologist
November 2009: 4 treatments of CyberKnife
December 2010:hesitantly started Nexavar : several ER visits and two hospital admissions
May 2011:after 5 months stopped Nexavar 
November 2011:6 months later:Chemo: Camptosar and 5FU, continuing every 2 weeks
March 1, 2012: Surgery to remove an ulcerated mass in colon; Nothing to do with FHC
May 16, 2012: admitted to hospital with difficulty breathing, shortness of breath: 2 liters of fluid removed from right lung
Dr. Kaseb: physician: Chemo recommendation: Avastin: Hopefully to begin after recovery from colon surgery
entry.Title: Kelly L
entry.Hospitals:
UAB Hospital in Birmingham Alabama ,
MD Anderson
entry.Locations:
Kirklin Clinic in Birmingham AL,
Houston Texas

entry.Description:
2 months of unexplained nausea, diarrhea,vomiting: Blood tests: slightly elevated AST , ALT
2 weeks later, saw gastroenterologist: multiple tests including screening for cancer antigen
All of the typical tumor marker and cancer antigens: within normal limits again masking a very serious disease that was progressing rapidly
Believed to be Irritable Bowel Syndrome
4 days later: ultrasound showed 7cm mass in the midportion of the liver
CAT scan performed immediately confirming the liver mass along with moderate ascites and peritoneal implants. FHC was confirmed by pathology reviewed by both the Cleveland Clinic and the University of Pennsylvania
10 days later: disease was progressing rapidly: due to the intra-abdominal metastases the liver tumor was determined to be unresectable/inoperable.
Surgery ruled out 
Systemic chemotherapy: Cisplatin and Doxorubicin initiated on August 25th
After first treatment:temperature, was extremely sick, a severe headache
Discontinued use of Zofran
began compazine(prochlorperazine) and dexamethasone
headaches stopped
Port placed 
side effects worsening:unable to eat, fluids building up in abdomen.
September 28:After cycle 2: CT reports:tumors increased: increase in ascites and other intraperitoneal tumors: health continued to deteriorate.
2 paracentesis procedures performed to draw off some of the fluid and give some relief
Unable to eat much, losing weight rapidly ,build up of fluids offsetting weight loss
Chemo halted for a couple of weeks
October:new Chemo regimen: 5-FU and Oxaliplatin 
November 2011: Scan indicated dramatic results:significant and almost immediate reduction in the ascites
discovered a pulmonary blood clot in lung
immediate ER visit to receive blood thinners
Prescribed daily shot of Lovenox, a blood thinner
Jan 31, 2012: scan showed a decrease in both the primary liver tumor and a decrease in the degree of peritoneal carcinomatosis
Continue on this course of treatment 
Some neuropathy
Nausea treated with Compazine/day;Promethazin/night
Does not tolerate anything cold for a day or two after treatment and then it goes away until the next treatment
Tags: Neuropathy (loss of feeling in fingers or toes)
entry.Title: Mike's Story
entry.Symptoms and Side Effects: Nausea, Loss of Appetite, Neuropathy (loss of feeling in fingers or toes), Diarrhea, Weight Loss

entry.Description:
32 years old, married 2 boys at the time
stomach bothering,"full" feeling, bad shoulder blade pain
suspected gall bladder problem or acid reflux
ultrasound showed a massive tumor on or in liver
referred to Dr. Stephen Bartos, out of Waukesha Memorial
MRI ordered
Surgery followed:1/3 of liver removed.:confirmed FHC: difficult recovery
Surgeon confident that he got it all
Referred to oncologist: Dr.LaMarbre: unfamiliar with FHC
CT every 3 months first year, then every 6 months
Followed up for 6 years
18 months after surgery: pregnant: delivered healthy boy
entry.Title: Holly K's story

entry.Description:
Jenny's courageous battle with Fibrolamellar involved an initial surgery that removed a grapefruit sized tumor from her liver. Unfortunately the cancer recurred about 10 months later. At first they planned to do another surgery, but eventually aborted in favour of doing chemotherapy instead. Jenny has been doing Nexavar. After some initial setbacks, she had to stop the treatment and then resume it at a lower dose, but has worked her way up to the full dose. Though she has some side effects, including fatigue and hair thinning, she is very upbeat and keeps living life to the fullest!

This is an inspiring story.
entry.Title: Jenny_s FHC story.doc

Besides discussing the treatment program, the interview covers other topics such as pancreatic enzymes, theories behind what causes cancer, and various studies conducted by the US government.

The treatment utilizes autologous natural killer cells, cyclophosphamide, and interleukin 5.
entry.Title: NK Trial - pediatric oncology.docx

entry.Description:
The author writes about personal experiences with surgery and chemo, and provides his advice and perspective based on those experiences.
Advice includes:
1) advocate for surgery for Fibrolamellar, even in the case of metastasis; only accept "no" as an answer when surgery is considered too risky/dangerous
2) 2nd opinions are important, and should be sought, especially from different hospitals than the one that provided the 1st opinion
3) consider the source for each medical opinion and give more weight to doctors with expertise in the field being discussed - i.e. a surgeon's opinion about surgery counts more than a chemo doctor
4) be clear on how aggressive you are prepared to be with your doctors - let them know whether you are wiling to take risks to get better results or if you want to play it safe
Tags: Surgery to Remove Tumors Outside of the Liver

entry.Description:
An announcement of a tool being created to help patients tell their stories effectively, organizing all of the key information and making it easy for them to share their story only with the people they want to share it with.

It is hoped that the tool could be used to gather together information from different patients' stories in a way that will be educational for doctors and patients alike.
entry.Title: MyFibrolamellarStory-BetaIntroNote.pdf

entry.Description:
Sandy Simon has created a "tissue repository" for storing tissue samples donated by patients with Fibrolamellar HCC. The tissues are taken from tumors that have been surgically removed and/or from biopsied tissue.

The tissues stored in the repository will be used by researchers to try to learn more about Fibrolamellar HCC.

entry.Description:
Sept. 2011: cold symptoms, persistent diarrhea, bloating
Oct: 3: CT scan revealed mass 
Oct: 14: FHC diagnosis confirmed: surgery offered + medication to manage pain and bloating
Medication not helpful
Oct. 19: CT scan repeated in Kansas City
Oct. 26:progression of disease:no longer surgical candidate: offfered Nexavar
2nd opinion sought from MD Anderson, Sloan Kettering Memorial
Offered 5FU/Interferon + paracentesis for bloating
Oct. 28: paracentesis performed: port placed for Chemo

32 days after the tumor was found and only two months after symptoms were noticed, Jay passed away.
entry.Title: Jay's Story

entry.Description:
Oct. 2011:symptoms of increased fatigue, nausea, vomiting, moderate back pain, and pressure/pain where the liver is on the stomach
Symptoms increased: vomiting and significant weight loss
Dec. 2011: went to hospital: CT scan showed 2 tumors:biopsy confirmed FHC
Referred to Mayo Clinic in Rochester
Surgery not an option due to vascular invasion and size of first tumor
Jan. 24, 2012: Y-90 treatment: good recovery from treatment
Adopted 100% organic diet and had Nutrition response testing
Feels very positive response to alternative treatment

Referred to Dr. Fong at Memorial Sloan Kettering
Surgery performed
2nd scan post op revealed metastasis near colon
Surgery performed
Few months post op: metastasis next to the heart, above the original first one
Surgery performed

No Chemo

The patient is doing well and has no evidence of disease several years after his last surgery.

ER admission

Now on Nexavar:maintaining

entry.Description:
Both Fibrolamellar and HCC
Jan. 25, 2011: diagnosed with 5 tumors of varying sizes in liver and one in portal vei I had gone into advanced liver failure
Jan. 31:Surgery performed: no chemo to follow
after 3 weeks body rejected sutures: necessitated packing wounds
@ 6 months post op: stomach flu: ultrasound performed:revealed 2 cm. mass behind pancreas:surgery considered: CT Scan and PET Scan revealed eleven lesions in lung
No longer surgical candidate
Chemo: 5FU: 6 infusions over 3 months
entry.Title: My FLHCC Story- Nina B.

entry.Description:
This entry describes the importance of finding knowledgeable doctors in treating FHC and being motivated, in control and organized.
Jan./Feb.2011:Cancer in portal vein and behind wind pipe.
Goal: shrink tumors in portal vein to be able to have surgery
Chemo: 5FU/Interferon: some response: change Chemo
Chemo: Avastin and Xeloda:more tolerable
August: start Embolized Radiation on liver and portal vein.

entry.Description:
This entry also notes the need to trust doctor and change doctors when necessary.
suspected gallbladder issue:Ultrasound and MRI showed mass on liver:surfery performed:post op FHC diagnosis confirmed: no Chemo
6 month scan thought to be clear: another tumor missed
1 year post op:another tumor: surgery not an option: 
Chemo: Xeloda + Cyberknife radiation
Deteriorated
Moved care to MD Anderson
Surgery and Whipple performed: some complications due to infections
@ 7 months later: Scan revealed 4 new tumors; No surgery
Chemo:5FU/Interferon: 7 months stable disease
Recurrence: Chemo:Xeloda and Avastin
Plan for Y90 radiation treatment

entry.Description:
This entry talks about being a 4-time Liver Cancer Survivor and also 10 year cancer survivor.Despite reoccurences , together with determined doctors, had surgeries and experimental chemo procedures. She also has given birth to 2 babies

1997:Diagnosis: Stage 4 FHC: surgery performed: Chemo followed:injected directly into the tumor though the groin: not successful
1998:repeat surgery:metastasis followed
1999: surgery to remove all metastases
2000:reoccurence: experimental procedure: Ethanol (alcohol) Embolization.: Successful
"So keep the faith, Keep the fight, and never give up"
entry.Title: My FLHCC Story - Katie S.

ER visit:blood work showed elevated liver enzymes:CAT scan of kidneys and liver revealed tumor on liver: not a surgical candidate: referred to MD Anderson
Chemo: response to 5FU/Interferon
Chemo: Avastin and Xeloda
Plan to start Emobilzed Radiation on liver and portal vein
